clinical_study.brief_title: Autogenic Drainage Effect on Blood Gases and Prevention of Hospital-acquired Pneumonia After Upper Abdominal Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Autogenic Drainage Effect on Blood Gases and Prevention of Hospital-acquired Pneumonia After Upper Abdominal Surgery

brief_summary.textblock: Purpose: This study will find out the effect of Autogenic drainage on the prevention of early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia after upper abdominal surgery. Method: forty patients post upper abdominal surgeries will be included, their ages ranged from 40 to 50 years old. The patients will be divided into two groups, study group (A) include 20 patients that receive first traditional physiotherapy (breathing exercise, percussion, vibration with postural drainage) then autogenic drainage (B)-Group B:20 patients that receive traditional physiotherapy (breathing exercise, percussion, vibration with postural drainage)

intervention.description: breathing control using expiratory airflow to mobilize secretions from smaller to larger airways. Secretions are cleared independently by adjusting the depth and speed of respiration in a sequence of controlled breathing techniques during exhalation in addition to traditional physiotherapy (breathing exercise, percussion, vibration with postural drainage

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age from 40 to 50 years
- Patients undergoing elective upper abdominal surgery with an abdominal incision longer than 5 cm that is above or extending above the umbilicus.
- Non-smoker patients
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients developing cancer
- Patients with rib fractures
- Inability to comprehend and follow instructions.
- Pre-existing obstructive sleep apnea or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
- Current hospital patient for a separate episode of care.
- Patients requiring esophageal surgery or organ transplant.
